comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
The London Times of April 8 1936 announced the provisional agreement for the go-ahead of the "Poulaphouca Scheme", also known as the "Griffith Moynihan Kettle Scheme" and the "Liffey Scheme".
This is a climax to efforts which have been made for many years by prominent Irish engineers with strong support from the press and the public. The scheme is designed to provide the city and county of Dublin with a water supply that will be adequate to their needs for many generations, and reinforce the Shannon Electrical Scheme by an independent source of power.
It sounds as if the scheme was sorely needed:
The need for these increased supplies is sadly evident. During recent sumers the lack of water has been felt severely in the neighbourhood of Dublin. In certain areas of the city it has been necessary at times to cut off supplies during certain hours, and in the rural and suburban areas there has been genuine distress.
The article adds that the lack of a reliable water supply meant that all housing development in the adjoining county and boroughs had come "to a sudden and undesirable stop".

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] And in the Irish Times September 1938, they called it the Griffth-Kettle-Moynihan Scheme! Wonder how much arguing went on as to the order of the names... :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: In Finnegan's Wake The Kettle-Griffith-Moynihan Scheme for a New Electricity Supply gets a mention. Perhaps they agreed to take turns.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Tongue Twister for Racegoers ORIGIN OF THE NAME Racegoers [in Australia 1922] have often what is the meaning of the word Poulaphouca, and many have tumbled over the name of Mr. T. G Doyle's hurdle winner. Poulaphouca it appears, is a wild chasm where the river LIffey falls over a ledge of rocks into a deep pool of the Puca (Pooka). The Puca is a goblin whose exploits are a mixture or merriment and malignity. Under the name of Puck he will be recognised as the 'merry wanderer of the night,' who boasts that he can run a girdle round the earth In 40 minutes.' ... ...
From - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/118852442
